column1: At close of business on 31 December 2021, will Apple be the most valuable publicly traded company in the world?
column4: Yes, the most valuable in the world
column5: ['Yes, the most valuable in the world', 'No, but the most valuable in the United States', 'No']
column6: ['Business', 'Technology']
Virtually certain that it is Apple...
My simulation suggests that the chance Apple will remain the most valuable company is now more than 99%. CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/apple_most_valuable/apple_relative.py
Apple has widened its significant lead over Microsoft and there isn't much time for things to change between now and the time of the question resolution.
The difference between AAPL and MSFT has widened to 14.5%, and there are only three weeks left.
still on vacation and not running simulations, but @samglover97 seems about right.
Gap between Microsoft and Apple is widening.
Apple is back to a pretty commanding lead now.
Microsoft is too far behind for 2021
Traveling and can't run simulations so just guessing... @JamesEE seems about right.
The gap between AAPL and MSFT is widening, now over 13% with less than four weeks to go.
The clock is running down.

The news of weakening iPhone 13 sales didn't have much effect on the AAPL stock price. While that could change, with only 4 weeks to go and with AAPL about 7.5% ahead of MSFT I'll move to the crowd's consensus at 79%

Bloomberg reported today that Apple has been telling suppliers that demand for the iPhone 13 has softened. See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-02/apple-tells-suppliers-iphone-demand-has-slowed-as-holidays-near?sref=x7nYEkiY Reducing the odds to 71%.

The difference between AAPL and MSFT is now over 10%. It will take a very negative announcement to pull AAPL down that far vis-a-vis MSFT. The odds of "YES" continue to increase. But, IMHO, the odds almost never go to either zero or 100%. I'll boost to 85%.
SIMULATION RESULT: {AAPL: 82%, MSFT: 18%, OTHER: 0%} CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/apple_most_valuable/apple_relative.py

The difference between AAPL and MSFT has increased from around 5% to over 7.5%. AAPL is one of the few stocks that are actually up today. Whatever the odds were yesterday, they are higher today for a "YES" answer.
SIMULATION RESULT: {AAPL: 63.897%, MSFT: 36.098%, OTHER: 0.005%} CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/apple_most_valuable/apple_relative.py
SIMULATION RESULT: {AAPL: 68.014%, MSFT: 31.98%, OTHER: 0.006%} CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/apple_most_valuable/apple_relative.py
The simulation now suggests that AAPL has a 66% chance of coming out on top based on recent price movements.
The simulation now suggests that AAPL has a 59% chance of coming out on top based on recent price movements.
The simulation now suggests that AAPL has a 54% chance of coming out on top based on recent price movements.

The Monte Carlo simulation suggests that the chances of Saudi Aramco being the most valuable have dropped below half a percent, so I'm rounding it down to zero. Meanwhile, I'm pretty much staying the same as this forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1353551
Passage of time, MSFT still a bit ahead

My "outside view" remains based on the Monte Carlo simulation as shown in this forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351709 However, I'm persuaded to updated based on @JamesEE 's recent comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1353140 I'm moving closer to even chances between MSFT and AAPL, but with a 1% chance ( 0.635% as per the simulation) of ARAMCO being the largest. The reason ARAMCO still has such a high chance is because AAPL and MSFT are highly correlated whereas ARAMCO is much more independent.

Apple's new M1 silicon for laptop computers is being recognized as a true breakthrough in performance. See https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/10/opinion/apple-microprocessor.html. Checking availability at apple.com, I found that if I were to order one today it would arrive early December.

No: - Microsoft recently passed Apple as the most valuable. $4Bn difference with Apple experiencing issues and bad PR. - Holidays will likely affect both companies equally, perhaps Microsoft better thanks to pricing. - Less than 2 months before closing date. - “Wall Street analysts say buy BoA, Microsoft & Alphabet” -CNBC

I put together a quick version of a Monte Carlo simulation that forces AAPL, MSFT, and ARAMCO to move according to how they are directionally correlated with respect to AAPL (e.g. in the real world, MSFT moves the same direction as AAPL about 77% of the time, so they must also share the same directionality 77% of the time in the simulation). I'm also using the same technique here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1349335
initial forecast following @elifland ... will try to build a model for my next forecast.
The latest boost I'm assuming is mostly from Q3 earnings, so I'm guessing there won't be as much big news to knock Microsoft back down below Apple by the end of the year.
Even though it is slightly less impacted by chip shortages, the chip shortages are not going away any time soon, and Microsoft will probably keep the top spot in the next few months.
Looks like Microsoft edged slightly ahead.
Oops.

Given that the value of MSFT now exceed AAPL, the odds have got to move at least a little bit higher for "NO." The crowd hasn't moved much, so either: the crowd is not paying much attention, or the crowd believes AAPL will rally before year end. It's probably some of both, but count me one of the "Apple will rally" folks. It's just somewhat less certain, IMHO.
Microsoft now beats apple. I am moving my prediction strongly know in order to make up for a long history. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/microsoft-surpasses-apple-worlds-most-valuable-stock
Currently the gap between Apple and Microsoft is less than 1% [1] with 2 more companies within 20% of Apple.
Choices are incorrect. Probabilities shouldn't sum up to 100%.
Upping no on the rise of Microsoft as mentioned by @JamesEE

Given the rapid rise in oil prices it's interesting that Saudi Aramco stock has increased less than 5% this year (35.00 to 37.30 riyals). The Vanguard Energy Sector ETF (symbol VDE) has increased close to 35% in 2021. But then Aramco is not a private company which seeks to benefit shareholders. Given that Aramco has vastly underperformed other oil-related stocks it seems doubtful that it will jump nearly 20% before Dec 31st.
Ugh what a time for Oil to jump and US can't increase output. Being forced to consider the possibility that Aramco still has has an outside chance at this point.

MSFT stock is up on the announcement of a price increase to its Office software. It's now only about 7% below AAPL in market cap, so I'll increase the odds a bit for "No." https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/blog/2021/08/19/new-pricing-for-microsoft-365/

Giving MSFT one chance in 16 to exceed AAPL. Aramco stock has consistently gone nowhere, even though the oil price seems to be sticking above $70/barrel. I'm betting (another question) that oil will go below $70/barrel before the end of 2021.
What am I missing? Per Bloomberg the market cap of Apple is $2.449T, and the market cap for Aramco is $6.940T . Why do most people think Apple will have a higher market cap in three days?

A few thoughts: -Apple has been top 1 or 2 in the world's most valuable companies for a while (number 1 for about 8 of the last 10 years) - However Microsoft is only approx. 15% below Apple in value and Amazon is approx. 30% below, all three stocks have a fair amount of volatility so reasonable chance one will leap frog (assigned 10%) -Assigned 10% chance Aramco will pull ahead of Apple

Again upping my estimate slightly for a No based on the chance that Microsoft could be a candidate. Microsoft earnings for the last 4 quarters is roughly around 51bn whereas for Apple the earnings for year ended Sept 20 were 57bn. As far as earnings growth is concerned Msoft has been growing faster led by its cloud business (outlook here is good, with companies being forced to invest in increasing their digital footprint because of the pandemic,work from home etc) Also Xbox revenues though relatively small for now for Msoft are also soaring. They are making inroads into AI (with their latest acquisition of Nuance). Though earnings for Msoft might not surpass Apple this year(ie FY21) but there does seem to be a fairly good chance this happens next year.

Microsoft is quickly closing in (just a 15% gap now between Apple and MS) With a better earnings growth than Apple and a stronger growth outlook across its all business verticals (especially cloud) there is a fair chance they may surpass Apple

Hoy en día, la empresa tecnológica Apple corresponde a la empresa más rentable del mundo con un valor de mercado de 2.2 billones de dólares. Además, sus ventas aumentaron de manera considerable durante el encierro por la pandemia del coronavirus. Esto, me lleva a pensar que a finales de este 2021 hay altas posibilidades de que mantenga esta posición. Sin embargo, debido al alza en el precio del petróleo, la empresa petrolera Saudi Aramco de Arabia Saudita podría reclamar el título. Ello me ha llevado a darle un 40% de probabilidades de que Apple sea la más cotizada en Estados Unidos. Con respecto al 5% de que ninguna de las opciones anteriores ocurra, se debe a otras empresas estadounidenses que han estado expandiéndose rápidamente, como Tesla y Amazon.
Edging up the odds of Microsoft outgrowing Apple.
Lack of innovation, just evolution will not raise value
It still looks like a battle between Saudi Aramco and Apple for the top spot. Microsoft and Amazon could make a run for it, but that seem less likely.

Apple sales are falling. Oil prices are rising. Starting in about May when CPI tops 2.5% all of the wealth effect that the Federal Reserve has created will start to reverse. Stocks like Apple that have gotten a disproportionate amount of the gains well now get a disproportionate amount of the losses. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/apple-reportedly-slashes-planned-iphone-12-mini-production-amid-slumping-demand
Per the sources cited in the question Apple's lead over ARAMCO has been reduced to about 3%. I'll up the odds for "No, but the most valuable in the US," very close to the crowd now.

With increasing oil prices and falling stock prices, Saudi Aramco is currently in the lead. Amazon and Microsoft are also closing the gap in the U.S. based companies. While I've adjusted the odds to reflect these changes, I believe oil prices will retreat before December. So I'm maintaining Apple as the most likely winner.

Oil price is climbing. OPEC has committed to not increasing production. rising inflation and rising interest rates will crash the stock market this year. Stock market favorites like Apple and Tesla and Netflix that have risen abnormally high in the bubble will correspondingly fall the most during this next downturn.

Amazon is a close competitor in the market capitalization metric. Amazon is prolific in its expansion strategy in e-retail, AI, etc. In the absence of anti-trust measures, Amazon will continue to grow bigger and faster. At the same time, Apple is seen as a product company ( yes, Apple stores has a big control in the app market). Hence, Amazon has far more chances than Apple.
Even with the bull run on oil prices, Saudi Aramco hasn't taken over the top spot. Unless something dramatic happens, Apple is posed to hold on.
according the NBC news, the company could see nearly "$60 billion in profit this year" and their only the second company to to cross the $2 trillion market capitalization mark.
This is NOT about market capitalization but only about the immaterial asset/goodwill position in the balance sheet, but it may be an indicator for where the journey is heading...

Apple continues to grow and spread the gap. The biggest risk to Apple's ranking remains Saudi Aramco, which has should have much lower price correlation than the other companies. Until another US company shows significantly faster growth (or more downside resilience) than Apple, the default answer should be yes.
No doubt about it.

In last 15 years, 4 companies Microsoft, Apple, Exxon Mobile and PetroChina have been the most valuable companies at the end of the year [1] Apple has been number 1 for last 8 out 10 years. Considering the above 2 points, I am estimating a base rate of about 60-70% of Apple being the most valuable company
In my head, I have to re-phrase this question.
Not sure which american company is betting on to overthrow Apple but I think people should start some arbitrage if they think Apple is so much likely to lose its throne

Conditions are too tight to be committed. It may happen during the year but as a close out value for 2021, there may be other parameters that may affect. inflation, forex, solar, energy, Microsoft, Aramco, and even Tesla.

The crowd has moved strongly towards "NO," which requires that one of the other tech companies passes AAPL. The most likely are MSFT and AMZN, but they have to make up a pretty large gap of over 33%. It has happened in the recent past, and could happen again. But I don't see it as the most probable event. A global economic recovery brought about by vaccines could make this a big year for energy. So it seems more likely that ARAMCO wins over big tech, or that AAPL keeps the lead.

Apple is currently the largest, so this answer will resolve to yes unless something changes the status quo. Thinking about how this question might become a "no" the companies to watch are Saudi Aramco, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Tesla, and Tencent. Apple loses the top spot if one or more of these companies grows faster than Apple, or if Apple loses more market capitalization than at least one of these companies.

The question to me is not so much which company appreciates fastest in 2021, because I do not expect the extraordinary year 2020 for the stock market to repeat, but instead which company in a very difficult year ahead will have such a stable and profitable (with regards to margins) business model that it is going to lose least market cap. The stock market isn't going to get any better than that. Apple has a good portfolio of software, hardware, services, even financial services, and is innovative enough to maybe become the first 3-trillion-USD company within five years. I don't think any competitor or contender in this question has an edge over Apple. A lot of impact on profitability (and thus market cap) will depend on tax regimes worldwide, and which of the (mostly) companies is best and most aggressive in negotiating the most ridiculously low tax rates in one of the many half-baked tax domiciles. Unless there is major consensus among G20 that tax fraud and evasion must end, and tax regimes finally change.
Potential upcoming tech regulation in the US, continued strength of Amazon with ongoing pandemic
See this being a big year for Microsoft.
Initial forecast -- with nearly one year to go anything can happen. I'm less confident about AAPL being #1 than the crowd.
If there is a market drop, likely Saudi Aramco will drop similarly to Apple. So the biggest chance for "No" is some tech company exceeding Apple's market cap.
Premium revenues may be threatened by COVID recession. Privacy concerns will help. Chinese mega Corps could well overtake, esp with better market access
Betting on Amazon or Ali
Since Apple first became the end of year most valuable publicly traded company in 2012 -> https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/30/microsoft-apple-end-trading-market-cap.html

I think there is a reasonable chance that gridlock in Congress will harm the economy and cut into the iphone market in combination with anti-trust issues brought on by the Epic Games suit. This coupled growth in China since they seem to be able to handle Covid. Also EVs are booming so its also possible that Tesla could over take them in the US, but that is less likely. They are pretty high though so it will take make that happen.

According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization#2020, absent large shifts in technology, the top three places in companies by market capitalization are largely stable and often occupied by the same group (past ten years - Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, BH, Exxon Mobil).
It's more likely that Apple will be most valuable in the US, than in world. And the least probable that no change would occur.
It looks reasonable that with the recently launched subscription services it would keep growing.

First, we may be entering a tech bubble that could burst during the year. Considering that Apple's competitors are also within this sector, a decline in their market cap would equate to the same for them. In a post-COVID environment, the oil/energy sector should see a rise that could generate additional market cap for ARAMCO that could allow it to pass Apple. Additionally, the Chinese economy and Alibaba (even with the investigation) could grow greater than any US competitor.
Very useful source : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization#2020

I looked at the daily year-on-year changes of the market cap of the big tech companies over the last 4 years and worked out how often, if extrapolated into the future, they would beat Apple's predicted (by the same method) minimum, lower/upper quartiles, and mean (I ignored the max in order to be a bit conservative). Weighting each equally, in 34% of cases one or both of Microsoft or Amazon had a higher predicted market cap. However, this assumed Aramco stays stable (as it roughly has since it floated). I don't know very much about Aramco, although I think it more likely than not that tech will grow faster than oil next year. I massaged the numbers a bit to reflect this uncertainty. As a sanity check I was pleased to see my somewhat idiosyncratic methodology produced a similar result to the current crowd forecast.
Microsoft and Amazon more likely given continued rise of cloud tech & enterprise comms during 2021

A year is a logn shot, but that's what makes it interesting. Going down into sub-questions, we can say: The Tech bubble. Just comparing current prices to Feb ones, there was a significant increase probably not justified by creation of value. My guess is there is a bubble that will burst with household savings being spent. Also, it seems that the winners from the pandemic are Apple and Amazon, for individual, stay-at-home reasons. Microsoft and Google also performed well, but not as well. The oil vs other cleaner energy. During this time, Aramco was relatively stable, about +10% variance to pre-COVID. Not that it makes a lot of sense with current oil prices compared to Feb. (just to compare, S&P 500 increased by 20% and DJIA by 18%). It doesn't seem reasonable that other options are considered in this situation and short period, and the barrel price could likely increase with activity. So, "all" is needed is Apple to drop about 16% to be below Market Cap of pre-COVID Aramco. At this point, it is more likely to happen than not. The other question would be In terms of the US companies and the competition between consumers and businesses. This is hard to say. The difference between Apple and Microsoft is huge, but the market correction, if there is any, would be too. Pre-COVID, both companies were aligned in Market Cap. My guess is that it will be slightly better for Microsoft or Amazon than for Apple, as business will still need their services, while fewer business will be open, but surely consumers will not need the latest iPhone or iPad. Sources: https://finance.yahoo.com
nah

Apple seems to be doing really well and the outlook for 2021 seems quite strong too with the macbook launch and another Ipad expected to be launched in Q1 2021. Moreover the iphone 12 has received a good response. Apples earnings have more or less been stagnant in the last 3-4 years.

Barred any major frictions in global supply chains or smashes to US, China or global purchase power and demand for CE, Apple R&D will likely be more productive economically than low tech pumping of crude oil. As KSA has one of the lowest production costs (likely still between 15 to 20USD/bbl) AND the one of the highest inventory of confirmed reserves worldwide Saudi Aramco's enterprise value will largely depend on the global average crude oil price level: if prices for SA grades rise to 50USD/bbl, then Saudi Aramco's earnings in the worst case will be 60cents on the dollat of sales, if prices climb to as much as 70USD/bbl, a level previously seen in the wake of the Sept 2019 Abqaiq–Khurais attack, its earnings are scaled up to 71cents on the dollar of sales. At a revenue of 329.8bn USD (FY 2019), Saudi had an operating income of 177,8bn USD (53.9%, FY2019) and a net income of 88.2bn USD (26.7% of revenue, FY 2019). Most of net income will be distributed as dividend in 2020 again, where both AAPL and Saudi Aramco have a similar peculiarity in their financial position and their financing structure, in that they use debt funding for dividend payments to lower costs of funding. "Aramco said it would distribute a dividend of $18.75 billion for the quarter, in line with its plan to pay a base dividend of $75 billion for 2020. But equity analyst Yousef Husseini at investment bank EFG-Hermes said Aramco would likely have to increase its debt financing in the short- to medium-term, or further cut capital expenditure, in order to be able to maintain the dividend unless oil prices recovered to at least $55 a barrel." https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-aramco-results-idUKKBN27J0K3

Apples increase in value in 2020 was largely due to the overall boom in the US stock market which was fueled by the easy money created by the federal reserve. This easy money tended to benefit certain places, such as high profile stocks such as FANG stocks. Therefore, any major stock market crash will likely see the opposite effect with a larger amount of value coming out of these overpriced stocks that have benefited the most from this bubble.

With the high value of tech stocks and the long timeframe on the question I feel more confident that a correction will happen at some point next year. But these things are hard to predict and a correction might not mean a big drop, it could mean slower gains as other companies catch up. Or I could be totally wrong and a correction won't even happen. I think there's a very good chance Apple stays as the most valuable company in the US since I think most other valuable tech stocks will continue to follow a similar trend as Apple does.
Helpful table here: https://companiesmarketcap.com/
